questions.question: If the universe started from nothing, what was there before nothing?
questions.story: In 1964, Arno Penzias heard static on a radio telescope. That static was the echo of the Big Bang - the universe literally speaking to us across 14 billion years. But it raised a terrifying question: what came before?
questions.thinker: Georges Lemaître, Catholic priest who proposed Big Bang
questions.followUp: Is 'before' even a valid concept without time?

questions.question: Why do you trust that tomorrow will have the same laws of physics as today?
questions.story: David Hume couldn't sleep. He realized we have no logical reason to believe the sun will rise tomorrow - just because it always has. This destroyed the foundation of science for 50 years.
questions.followUp: What if physics changes, but our memories change too?

questions.question: If you replaced your neurons one by one with silicon chips, at what point would you stop being you?
questions.story: Theseus's ship was preserved by Athenians. As planks decayed, they replaced them. Eventually, every plank was new. Was it still Theseus's ship? You replace all your cells every 7 years. Are you still you?
questions.followUp: What exactly is the 'you' that persists?

questions.question: How do you know you're not the only conscious being in existence?
questions.story: Descartes locked himself in a room with an oven. In the warmth, he doubted everything - except that he was doubting. But he could never prove anyone else was conscious. Neither can you.
questions.followUp: Would it matter if you were alone?

questions.question: If we discovered the equation that predicts every human decision, would free will cease to exist?
questions.story: Laplace imagined a demon who knew every atom's position. It could predict everything - including your next thought. Einstein believed this. Heisenberg destroyed it. But what if Einstein was right?
questions.followUp: Can you choose differently knowing you're predicted to choose?

questions.question: Why does mathematics - a human invention - perfectly describe nature?
questions.story: Eugene Wigner called it 'unreasonable.' Why do imaginary numbers describe real electricity? Why does geometry from ancient Greece predict black holes? Is math discovered or invented?
questions.followUp: Did we invent math, or did math invent us?

questions.question: If you could experience someone else's consciousness for one minute, would you still be you when you returned?
questions.story: Thomas Nagel asked 'What is it like to be a bat?' We can never know. Your 'red' might be my 'blue.' We're trapped in our own consciousness. But what if we weren't?
questions.followUp: How do you know you returned to the right consciousness?

questions.question: Why does the universe exist in a form that allows us to ask why it exists?
questions.story: The Anthropic Principle haunts physics. Change any constant by 0.0001% and atoms don't form. No stars. No life. No questions. Are we impossibly lucky, or is this backwards?
questions.followUp: Do questions create the universe that allows them?

questions.question: If every atom in your body came from stars, are you the universe experiencing itself?
questions.story: Carl Sagan realized we are 'star stuff contemplating star stuff.' Your carbon came from stellar furnaces. Your consciousness from cosmic evolution. You're not in the universe - you ARE the universe.
questions.followUp: Is consciousness what the universe does, or what it is?

questions.question: Can something be true if no conscious being will ever know it?
questions.story: A tree falls in an empty universe. Not just no one around - no conscious beings exist anywhere, ever. Did it make a sound? Does it even make sense to say it 'fell'?
questions.followUp: Does truth require a witness?

questions.question: If time is relative, is there a 'now' that exists across the universe?
questions.story: Einstein destroyed simultaneous time. Your 'now' includes alien civilizations' past and future. There's no universal present moment. So when you say 'now,' what do you mean?
questions.followUp: Are all moments equally real?

questions.question: Why do we find nature beautiful when beauty serves no evolutionary purpose?
questions.story: Darwin was troubled. His theory explained everything except why we're moved by sunsets. Beauty doesn't help survival. Yet a canyon's majesty can make you weep. Why?
questions.followUp: Is beauty a cosmic accident or cosmic intention?

questions.question: If you could press a button to eliminate all suffering, but also all joy, would you?
questions.story: Buddha saw that life is suffering. Schopenhauer agreed. But Nietzsche said suffering creates meaning. Without valleys, no mountains. Without pain, no growth. What's the point of comfort?
questions.followUp: Is suffering a bug or a feature?

questions.question: How can you be certain you're awake right now and not dreaming?
questions.story: Zhuangzi dreamed he was a butterfly. When he woke, he wondered: was he a man who dreamed of being a butterfly, or a butterfly dreaming of being a man? You've never been sure you're dreaming while dreaming.
questions.followUp: What if waking up is just another layer of dream?

questions.question: If atoms are 99.99% empty space, why can't you walk through walls?
questions.story: Rutherford shot particles at gold foil. Most passed through - atoms are empty. You're mostly nothing. The wall is mostly nothing. Yet electromagnetic forces create the illusion of 'solid.' What is touching?
questions.followUp: If nothing truly touches, are you ever really anywhere?

questions.question: Why do you believe your memories are real and not implanted five minutes ago?
questions.story: Bertrand Russell realized the universe could have been created 5 minutes ago with all memories intact. Every archaeological artifact, every memory - all created together. You can't disprove it.
questions.followUp: Would it matter if your past never happened?

questions.question: If evolution optimizes for survival, why did it create beings who contemplate their own death?
questions.story: Terror Management Theory: humans are the only animals who know they'll die. This knowledge terrorizes us, drives culture, religion, art. Evolution created mortality awareness. Why?
questions.followUp: Is consciousness evolution's mistake or masterpiece?

questions.question: Can you imagine a color that doesn't exist?
questions.story: Mantis shrimp see 16 types of color receptors. You have 3. They see colors you can't imagine. But 'imagine' means forming a mental image. Can you imagine the unimaginable?
questions.followUp: How many impossibilities are you blind to?

questions.question: If everyone on Earth blinked at once, would darkness exist for that moment?
questions.story: Schrödinger's cat is alive and dead until observed. Quantum physics suggests observation creates reality. If no one observes light, does it exist? Are you creating reality by looking?
questions.followUp: Does the universe exist between your blinks?

questions.question: Why does 'nothing' terrify us more than 'something terrible'?
questions.story: Sartre faced 'the nothing' and felt nausea. We fear death not because it's painful but because it's nothing. We'd rather eternal torture than non-existence. Why does nothing frighten?
questions.followUp: Can nothing be something to fear?

questions.question: If you could know exactly when you'll die, would you want to?
questions.story: The Oracle at Delphi gave prophecies that always came true - because people made them true. Oedipus fled his fate and ran straight into it. Does knowing the future create it?
questions.followUp: Would knowing when change how?

questions.question: How do you know the laws of logic are true if you need logic to prove them?
questions.story: Gödel destroyed mathematics in 1931. He proved you can't prove mathematics is consistent using mathematics. Every system of logic assumes its own truth. Circular forever.
questions.followUp: Is reason ultimately unreasonable?

questions.question: If humans vanished tomorrow, would the universe notice?
questions.story: Earth existed 4.5 billion years without us. The universe, 14 billion. We've been here 0.004% of cosmic time. Yet we think we're the point. What if we're a footnote?
questions.followUp: Does significance require someone to assign it?

questions.question: Why can you imagine impossible things but not experience them?
questions.story: You can imagine a square circle, backwards time, being in two places. Your mind breaks physics constantly. But experience obeys strict rules. Why is imagination freer than reality?
questions.followUp: Is imagination more real than experience?

questions.question: If every choice creates parallel universes, are you responsible for what your other selves do?
questions.story: Hugh Everett III proposed every quantum event splits reality. Every choice you didn't make, another you did. Infinite versions of you exist. Are they you? Are you them?
questions.followUp: Is there a 'real' you among infinite yous?

questions.question: Can you want to want something you don't want?
questions.story: Harry Frankfurt explored higher-order desires. You want to want to exercise, but you don't want to exercise. Which want is the 'real' you? Can you choose your wants?
questions.followUp: Who's choosing if not your wants?

questions.question: If consciousness is just electrical patterns, could a thunderstorm be thinking?
questions.story: Your brain is 86 billion neurons firing electrically. A thunderstorm has electrical patterns of similar complexity. We assume it's not conscious. But how would we know?
questions.followUp: What else might be thinking that we ignore?

questions.question: Why did the universe wait 14 billion years to experience itself through you?
questions.story: You are the universe's first chance to know itself in this exact way. Your specific consciousness has never existed before and never will again. Why now? Why you?
questions.followUp: Are you the universe's question or answer?

questions.question: If meaning requires an ending, does immortality make life meaningless?
questions.story: Borges imagined immortals who became utterly bored. Without death, nothing matters - infinite time to do everything makes everything equal to nothing. Does death give life meaning?
questions.followUp: Would you trade meaning for forever?

questions.question: What question would change everything if you knew the answer?
questions.story: Socrates claimed wisdom was knowing what you don't know. Every answer creates new questions. But perhaps there's one question whose answer would end all questions. What would you ask?
questions.followUp: Would you want to know, or keep wondering?
